conversation.content: Maya? Haven't seen you since what, three years ago at Tommy's wedding? You look like you've been carrying the whole world on your shoulders today.

Yeah, it's been forever, Sam. I just finished a rough shift at the tissue bank and needed something normal, something that doesn't involve sterile rooms and paperwork about people who aren't coming home.
[concerned] The usual? Rocky road with extra marshmallows, the way you ordered it every Friday after school when we thought life's biggest problem was passing chemistry?
[wistful] You remember that? God, those were simpler times. Today I processed tissue from a seventeen-year-old girl, same age as your sister was when she passed.
[quietly] Sarah would have been twenty-eight next month. Sometimes when I'm scooping birthday cake flavor, I still think about the party we never got to throw for her eighteenth.

[voice catching] This girl today, she had the same dark hair, same stubborn chin in her donor photo. Her corneas are going to help two people see, but all I could think about was how young she looked. [exhales]
[gently] Here, let me make you a sundae the way we used to share them, back when we believed ice cream could fix anything that hurt.
The family wrote a letter saying she wanted to be a nurse, wanted to help people heal, and now in a way she is, through what she left behind.

[soft] That's the thing about giving, isn't it? Whether it's tissue that saves lives or ice cream that brings someone comfort on their worst day, we're all just trying to make things a little better. [pause]
How do you do it, Sam? Stand here every day making people happy with something so simple when you know how complicated everything really is?

[thoughtfully] Because complicated doesn't mean we stop trying to find sweetness. I learned that from Sarah, actually—she kept asking for strawberry ice cream even when she couldn't taste it anymore during chemo.
[trembling] Sometimes I wonder if I'm strong enough for this job, handling these gifts from people who won't get to finish their stories. [quieter] Today really got to me.
[firmly] You're doing work that matters, Maya. Every tissue sample you process, every family you help through the donation process, that's someone's second chance at life.
It's just hard when they're so young, when they remind you of people you've lost, when you realize how fragile everything really is.
[warmly] Remember what we used to say when Sarah was sick? That grief is just love with nowhere to go, so we put it into what we do.
[understanding dawning] That's why you work here, isn't it? Not just scooping ice cream but creating these small moments of joy, the kind Sarah loved.
[simply] Every cone I serve is a tiny celebration that we're still here, still trying, still believing that sweetness matters even when life is bitter.
[softly] Thank you, Sam.
[lighter] Eat your sundae before it melts. And Maya? That seventeen-year-old's gift means someone else gets to order ice cream with their family for years to come. [gentle laugh]
[finally smiling] You're right. Tomorrow I'll go back and process more donations, help more families, because that's how we honor them—by continuing the work. [peaceful sigh]
